Description: Design for a surround of a votive image with God the Father and the Dove of the Holy Spirit above, a Bishop saint (St Antoninus?) and St Agatha with her breasts on a platter behind her on the left; St Antony of Abbot holding a bell and St Veronica holding the Sudarium on the right; a view of Hell with figures in torment below Red chalk over black chalk Verso: A nude female bather seen from behind, her arms raised Red and white chalk
Curator's comments: The design on the recto is for figures adoring an earlier miraculous image as in Paolo Gerolamo Piola's drawing in the BM, 1943,0710.7. As is observed in the Edinburgh catalogue, the miracolous image is likely to have been the Virgin which would explain the Annunciation narrative (God the Father sending down the dove of the Holy Spirit) in Furini's surround.
Exhibition history: 1972, Edinburgh, Merchants' Hall, 'Italian 17thc. Drawings from British Private Collections', no. 52
Subjects: god the father and the holy spirit
Associated names: Representation of: Bishop Antoninus of Florence (St Antoninus)
Representation of: St Antony of Egypt
